B0019LY5IM|5.0|In more ways than one, Lost Season 5 is the best season of one of the greatest shows ever to air on television. It had all the elements that have come to define the show, and make it one of the most enjoyable experiences ever to hit TV. It had great character development, it had great mythology, it had great moments, it was original, and it had a superb story. And let me start off by saying that I'm a time-travel geek. I lay awake at night in fear of time paradoxes and my life being erased. I've also seen most major & obscure takes on the subject, so I followed and understood the whole season with the information that was given. I can see how somebody would get lost easily, but I understood it perfectly, and that's just because of my geekiness. Your experience with Season 5 may vary.<br /><br />Highlight Episodes:<br />The Life and Death of Jeremy Bentham<br />LaFleur<br />Namaste<br />Dead Is Dead<br />The Incident<br /><br />First off, the characters. Ever since Season 1, Lost has struggled with bringing new emotions, and stories that seem like they fit with the character, and not for any cheap or uninteresting side-note or plot device; that is if they even move the characters along. In Season 5, this is not the case, every character matures in a totally different way than we've seen before, and it does them justice. This is especially the case with Sawyer, who after 5 Seasons has finally granted my wish of wanting to see him in a leadership role. But he's no leader like any we've seen on the show before, and he's certainly no Jack. He's still the cool, nickname guy we knew before, but this is a Sawyer that uses his brain for somebody other than himself, and he just does it in some have called a \\"Winston Churchill\\" type manner. And this description would suit him well. We finally found a stable relationship for Sawyer, and for a long while there, he was one of the few characters on the show that had found some sense of happiness. Jack, Kate, Hurley, Sayid & Sun also progressed well from off-island life to island life, giving each of the characters a real reason to return that again suited their characters well. Heck, even Kate or Jack didn't seem annoying for a while there. Then of course, we saw Miles & Faraday grow into their roles on the show, as they became not only essential to the story, but they found a way into our likability circle. Sure, they may have came late, but especially in the case of Miles now, he fits right in.<br /><br />Story-wise, the season does start off a bit slow do to the whole 'We're Getting The Band Back Together' storyline. Sure it was essential, but it felt like it could have been condensed a bit. But that only lasts for a few episodes, and they're usually inter-spliced with the time-travel story (More on Time-travel later). But once everybody got onto the island, it just rocketed down the path of no return with each episode being slammed-packed with great moments & stuff we've never seen before. Keeping the show on the island, but moving it mostly to the 70s was a great change of pace for the season, and it was fun living in the Dharma world for a little bit, getting to know the characters, events & the company that shaped the island so much, even though we wished Radzinsky had bit the bullet early from the moment he started opening his mouth. But overall, I couldn't have been much more satisfied with the arch the season took, and it did a nice job of setting up the final season.<br /><br />As for the time-travel, I was stunned how the show took it in such an amazing/original direction. I mean, the whole island moves in time, stays in one spot for a while, then takes the castaways to another time period. And some of the stops are pretty amazing. We get to see the island in the 50s, the future, the 80s, and other various unknown points, and what the castaways usually found in these periods was just so fun for any Lost fan. I mean, the moment where the island skips in time, and a rope once dangling from a well was just sticking out of the ground since the well hadn't been built yet. So awesome. But that's not all folks, they presented time travel theories, created the time-loop timeline, and dived deep into the question of 'Can you change the past, or is what done is done? If you try to change the past, do you just eventually set it on its present course?' These are deep questions, and it was just so fun to watch Lost tread ground that most other media hasn't even touched on, much less delved into.<br /><br />Overall, time will tell its true placement in the series' hierarchy, but for me, it was one of the most fun and satisfying experiences watching TV in my lifetime. Sure, it's not for everybody, and it is hard to get a grip on it, but for those that can (and it certainly helps to watch all the episodes in a short span of time), then you might be half as keen to love it as I do. And what about those last 30 seconds? One of the best cliffhangers in TV history, especially if you have the chance to pop in the next episode right afterwards? I say yes.since the well hadn't been built yet. So awesome. But that's not all folks, they presented time travel theories, created the time-loop timeline, and dived deep into the question of 'Can you change the past, or is what done is done? If you try to change the past, do you just eventually set it on its present course?' These are deep questions, and it was just so fun to watch Lost tread ground that most other media hasn't even touched on, much less delved into.    Overall, time will tell its true placement in the series' hierarchy, but for me, it was one of the most fun and satisfying experiences watching TV in my lifetime. Sure, it's not for everybody, and it is hard to get a grip on it, but for those that can (and it certainly helps to watch all the episodes in a short span of time), then you might be half as keen to love it as I do. And what about those last 30 seconds? One of the best cliffhangers in TV history, especially if you have the chance to pop in the next episode right afterwards? I say yes.

B002ZTQVGQ|4.0|Alright, I've heard many good reviews of Ponyo and a few negative ones. I can definitely see what there is to like, because there is much, but I also see where the film could have fallen short in the eyes of many viewers. I am not a strong fan of anime, but my friends are. I do like anime though; I think many artists and storytellers have achieved great things through their works in anime but, for me, nothing compares to the works of Hayao Miyazaki. He seems to capture a magic in his visuals paired with his song choices and overall tone. I am a huge fan of Spirited Away, Princess Mononoke, and Howl's Moving Castle, and I have become a fan of Ponyo. The reason I give this movie four stars is not because I do not like it, but because I felt it wasn't as strong as Miyazaki's other films. The four stars is based on a comparison which I probably should not even have made. This is why I say: if you're buying Ponyo because you love Miyazaki and you love the intricate details in the storytelling as well as the epic storyline (like Princess Mononoke), you will not get it here. This movie is more contained, simpler. Does that make it a bad movie? Heck no! On the contrary, Ponyo's simplicity is what makes it so great. It is the kind of movie that tells a simple enough story, but manages to bombard your eyes with beautiful, colorful images that are not simplistic in any way. I do recommend this movie; but don't do what I did: don't go in there expecting a two hour epic anime like Spirited Away or Princess Mononoke, because it is not those movies. Allow yourself to be taken in and don't expect too much, because sometimes too much is not a good thing. Ponyo is just enough. Enjoy!

0684824906|5.0|Doris Kearns Goodwin has shown again why she is one of the greatest historians of this generation. I understand the scandals that have arisen about possible plagiarism, but Kearns Goodwin writes great history. In this book, she not only gives detailed stories of the lives of these great men and their families. She also probes the motivation of the men who are the characters in the book and the issues that controlled the political climate of the period from 1840 to 1860.   But Kearns Goodwin gives us much more even than this. She takes you to the era about which she writes. She tells you what clothes were being worn, what was for sale in the stores, how influential newspapers of the time were and how dirty train rides were.  Pick up this book and take yourself back to the 1850s and live the lives these great men lived.

B001HN69B8|4.0|THE IMAGINARIUM OF DOCTOR PARNASSUS<br /><br />STARRING: Heath Ledger, Christopher Plummer, Andrew Garfield, Tom Waits, Lily Cole, Verne Troyer, Colin Farrell, Johnny Depp and Jude Law<br /><br />WRITTEN BY: Terry Gilliam and Charles McKeown<br /><br />DIRECTED BY: Terry Gilliam<br /><br />Rated: PG - 13<br />Genre: Science Fiction / Fantasy<br />Release Date: 08 January 2010<br />Review Date: 31 January 2010<br /><br />I've always found Heath Ledger and Johnny Depp to look similar, and thought it would be neat to see them play brothers. Obviously with the un-expected death of Heath Ledger, we will never see that happen. We can at least however, see them play the same character in the newest and last film of Ledger's life: The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus.<br /><br />Christopher Plummer co-stars as the magnificent Doctor Parnassus. He's an old-timer with a two-bit sideshow act that he barely seems content with. And when I say old-timer, I mean old. He's made a deal with the devil you see, that upon her 16th birthday, his daughter's soul will belong to the devil, granting Parnassus the gift of immortality. He made this deal, years before the birth of his daughter; but he made it nonetheless.<br /><br />All may not be lost for him however, when the devil (Tom Waits), offers him a new challenge. They will both attempt to collect the souls of five unfortunates, in just two days; the amount of time before his daughter turns 16.<br /><br />Desperate to keep her on earth with him, the old man regrettably agrees to the bet and the clock starts ticking. It's by sheer magic that Doctor Parnassus will be able to claim these five souls. All he has to do is get five people to willingly step into his `Imaginarium'; a curtain of sorts, onboard his portable side-show trolley. The `Imaginarium' is a kind of mystical dream-world that is different for all who enter.<br /><br />Parnassus sets hard at work with his crew of co-stars: his daughter Valentina (Lily Cole); the young man, who is infatuated with her, Anton (Andrew Garfield); and of course the mysterious Tony, played primarily by Ledger.<br /><br />We meet Ledger's character Tony in the most unpleasant and ironic of ways. He appears to be dead, hanging by the neck from a bridge. It will no-doubt put many in an uncomfortable place. He is magically revived and claims to have no memory of who he is or from where he hails. The team of small-time entertainers is in agreement that he can repay them for saving his life by joining their act. Tony accepts the invitation.<br /><br />All of the actors in the film deliver great performances and are a lot of fun to watch. You will laugh a lot too. This is not a great movie by any means, but it is a good one; especially if you take into consideration how extraordinarily well it was put together.<br /><br />Ledger passed away on 22 January 2008, leaving his co-stars and crew with the film only two thirds completed. Whatever were they to do? Co-writer and director Terry Gilliam (who had worked with Ledger previously on another good movie - The Brothers Grimm), had a great task ahead of him. He decided to make Ledger's character Tony into a shape shifter.<br /><br />By divine chance, they were able to transform the missing pieces of the film around the ones with Ledger, with the help of some Hollywood big-shots; Johnny Depp, Jude Law and Colin Farrell, to be exact. They all volunteered to act out the missing pieces of the story that requiring Tony. They could not have done it any better if they tried. The film plays out beautifully with all four actors, playing the same character in different stages of the story.<br /><br />Johnny Depp looks so much like Heath Ledger, there is one shot in the film that I'm not sure which one of them it is. Look for it and see if you can tell. It's the shot of Tony atop of the trolley after his first transformation into - the Johnny Depp version of himself. Depp perfected Ledger's character terrifically and it puts a smile on your face, knowing he stepped up to do this.<br /><br />Jude Law plays the second transformation and surprisingly enough, also looks like Ledger somewhat! He too played the character as Ledger would have and it's a treat to watch.<br /><br />But the biggest surprise to me came from Colin Farrell. Next to Ledger, he spends the longest time as Tony, and he blew me away with his performance. Knowing that he has a very thick Irish accent to cover up, it is astonishing at how similar his speech pattern was to that of Ledger's. He moves like Ledger, he looks like him and all of his facial expressions and physical mannerisms are dead-on. He is very deserving of a best supporting actor Oscar nomination.<br /><br />I liked Heath Ledger when I first saw him in 10 Things I Hate about You. But when I saw him in The Patriot, I knew he had a bright future ahead of him and I became an instant fan. I was taken aback by his outstanding performance in Brokeback Mountain, and no-one was a bigger fan of his portrayal of The Joker in The Dark Knight. It's easily one of the top ten performances by any actor in the history of cinema.<br /><br />There is a lot of speculation that he killed himself. I'm not a mind reader and I won't pretend to be. But having seen him in countless interviews, and witnessed his true passion for acting, I just can't buy that he would take his own life in the middle of a film, leaving his co-stars and friends to pick up the pieces. Keep in mind he came back to work with Terry Gilliam a second time, so obviously he had a good relationship with the man. Regardless of what happened to him in that lonely room in New York, - we miss you Heath. And thank-you for the cinematic treasures, you've left us with.sformation and surprisingly enough, also looks like Ledger somewhat! He too played the character as Ledger would have and it's a treat to watch.      But the biggest surprise to me came from Colin Farrell. Next to Ledger, he spends the longest time as Tony, and he blew me away with his performance. Knowing that he has a very thick Irish accent to cover up, it is astonishing at how similar his speech pattern was to that of Ledger's. He moves like Ledger, he looks like him and all of his facial expressions and physical mannerisms are dead-on. He is very deserving of a best supporting actor Oscar nomination.      I liked Heath Ledger when I first saw him in 10 Things I Hate about You. But when I saw him in The Patriot, I knew he had a bright future ahead of him and I became an instant fan. I was taken aback by his outstanding performance in Brokeback Mountain, and no-one was a bigger fan of his portrayal of The Joker in The Dark Knight. It's easily one of the top ten performances by any actor in the history of cinema.      There is a lot of speculation that he killed himself. I'm not a mind reader and I won't pretend to be. But having seen him in countless interviews, and witnessed his true passion for acting, I just can't buy that he would take his own life in the middle of a film, leaving his co-stars and friends to pick up the pieces. Keep in mind he came back to work with Terry Gilliam a second time, so obviously he had a good relationship with the man. Regardless of what happened to him in that lonely room in New York, - we miss you Heath. And thank-you for the cinematic treasures, you've left us with.

B001HNE3NO|3.0|The majority of our book club members didn't know about the events in Paris 1942 so we were overwhelmingly appalled by the atrocities which occurred during the Vel d'Hiv round-up. The author's vivid descriptions of the conditions in the Vel D'Hiv reveal not only the horror but also the many human reactions (good and bad) of all the participants. Our book club had a lively discussion about the Vichy government, collaboration and on a more personal note, the personality traits and displays of character by Sarah's parents. AND ... we all agreed that the contemporary time story fell short and disappointed us in many ways. The appearance of Sarah's son and Julia's connection to him were the last in a long line of trite and coincidental events that marred the contemporary time story. BUT ... if your book club is looking for a book that will spark discussion, read Sarah's Key.
B001B2KUIS|4.0|When Clapton was with the Yardbirds he quit before they released their first album \\"For Your Love\\" in protest for the more commercial-sounding material - a departure from mainstream blues ala what he did with John Mayall - of most of the tracks on that album.  Somewhat in a blessing in disguise, his actions allowed for my favourite guitarist of all time, Jeff Beck, and Jimmy Page to get involved with Page later on morphing the remnants of The Yardbirds into what eventually became Led Zeppelin.  So given how it all turned out I forgive Clapton's naivety/arrogance as now in what almost smacks of hyprocrisy or perhaps maturity of adulthood Clapton releases an album that is even more syrupy/commercial than \\"For Your Love\\" ever was!<br /><br />Still, that said, this is a very good album and although not as rewarding for me personally as was his work with Cream as being a guitarist myself I was more impressed with his incredible guitar stylings then and even with the Yardbirds (check out the guitar solos on \\"I Ain't Got You\\" and \\"Good Morning Little Schoolgirl\\" for instance - absolutely inspired stuff!) but still moving on to the relative simplicity of his playing on \\"Wonderful Tonight\\" this is clearly meant to reach out to a wider audience than what he had during those early days and he succeeds very well with the tracks here.  Long gone are the extended virtuoso guitar solos but we do get to see Clapton's vastly improving songwriting skills here although there are still quite a few covers (4 out of the 9 tracks are covers).<br /><br />This mini-lp replica sleeve (mlps) version is a slightly mixed bag though as although it has been remastered the sound quality is good but not great but this could be a result of a poorly preserved master.  There are also 2 foldout inserts containing all the lyrics in both English and Japanese.  The mlps design itself is very good and while not the best design that I've seen is still pretty well done and is not the worst that I've seen.<br /><br />Overall a decent mlps version of a decent Clapton album and a worthwhile addition to your sonic library.<br /><br />Recommended!ent mlps version of a decent Clapton album and a worthwhile addition to your sonic library.    Recommended!

B001H7SJLC|4.0|The \\"Scythe \\"ITA KAZE\\" Slim Hard Disk Cooler (SCIT-1000)\\" though appearing to be a Japanese product by name (Ita Kaze = Flat Wind) and packaging, is in fact, made in China (see photo). In a separate compartment in the box, is a wire harness for adapting the Ite Kaze fan, 3 pin connector to a 4 pin Molex style connector (see photo).<br /><br />Nowhere on the package or on the fan itself, does the Scythe Ita Kaze cooler specify the rated electrical characteristics of the fan in terms of volts (V), amps (A), and watts (W). Therefore, the end user is not able to calculate the nominal power requirement for the fan.<br /><br />After removing from the box, I was disappointed to see that the Ita Kaze aluminum heat sink was warped (see photo). Since the heat sink is made from thin soft aluminum, I was able to straighten out the warpage and lucky, not leave behind any high or low spots on the heat sink's interface surface.<br /><br />Minor, but a possible indication of inconsistent processes and manufacturing, the Scythe Ita Kaze heat sink I received, arrived with a low quality black finish on the anodized surfaces (see photo).<br /><br />The Scythe Ita Kaze cooler uses a single 100mm high efficiency fan with 13 scimitar shaped blades (see photo) as appose to two smaller 60mm fans with less CFM capacity. With the larger diameter fan rotor, the Scythe cooler evacuates more heat but also generates less noise as the Ite Kaze fan operates at a lower RPM.<br /><br />Thermally, a Vantec 3.5\\" Aluminum Hard Drive Cooler on a Hitachi 7200 RPM, 2TB SATA hard drive operating at 106F, by comparison on an identical drive with an Ite Kaze cooler, (see photo) runs at 104F, as per a Kintrex IRT0421 IR Thermometer.<br /><br />Item was promptly shipped by CableHero.<br /><br />Minus 0.25 for receiving a warped aluminum heat sink.<br />Minus 0.25 for the low quality finish on the anodized surfaces.<br />Minus 0.25 for not specifying the electrical requirements of the fan.<br />Minus 0.25 for the factory packaging having little structural support.Minus 0.25 for receiving a warped aluminum heat sink. 0316010669|5.0|In this well-written and easy-to-read book, Malcolm Gladwell explores the ways our first impressions and judgments are formed. It approaches this theme from both the positive and negative points of view, showing how oftentimes our first instinct can be the correct one even when the evidence seems to show something different, while at other times our snap judgments can be based on faulty physiological and socially-conditioned mechanisms. Gladwell includes examples from a variety of disiplines, from science and war to marketing and the arts. Some reviewers have criticized the author for not providing more of science to validify his theory. However, Gladwell is not a scientist, and he is not attempting to posit a new and wide-ranging theory for the world to accept. Gladwell's strength is in making the science of everyday concepts accessible and applicable for readers who may not otherwise read about such a topic. The book succeeds in making the reader question and think about the conclusions we reach - both in the heat in the moment and after conscious deliberation. He also offers potential guidelines for deciding when each is preferrable. Some of the issues he probes are of vital importance in how individuals and institutions make decisions in a variety of fields, which makes his book of great importance as well as of great interest.<br /><br />On a personal note, I found this book to intersect very nicely with some of my own research into the role of technique and structure in creativity, improvisation, and flow. The real-life examples Gladwell provides definitely make the topic engaging and alive, which I believe is very necessary in getting important messages across in a way that is accessible to people from a variety of backgrounds and education levels. So as a researcher and as a writer, I found Gladwell's book to be very valuable.
B002SF9YNO|5.0|Even though this film is in Japanese  this will not make any differents  you will see the emotions of the characters'  and know what they are feeling .Director Yojiro Takita and writer Kundo Koyama examine the rituals surrounding death in Japan with this tale of an out-of-work cellist who accepts a job as a \\"Nokanashi\\" or \\"encoffineer\\" (the Japanese equivalent of an undertaker) in order to provide for himself and his young wife. Daigo Kobayashi (Masahiro Motoki) is a talented musician, but when his orchestra is abruptly disbanded, he suddenly finds himself without a source of steady income. Making the decision to move back to his small hometown, Daigo answers a classified ad for a company called \\"Departures,\\" mistakenly assuming that he will be working for a travel agency. Upon discovering that he will actually be preparing the bodies of the recently deceased for their trip to the afterlife, Daigo accepts the position as gatekeeper between life and death and gradually gains a greater appreciation for life. But while Daigo's wife and friends universally despise his new line of work, he takes a great amount of pride in the fact that he is helping to ensure that the dead receive a proper send-off from this state of being. - Jason Buchanan, All Movie Guide I do highly recommend this film

1594488843|5.0|What really drives people to perform at their best? According to Daniel Pink, far too many managers rely on the carrot/stick approach to motivate employees. He cites substantial scientific research that shows that these approaches are outmoded and simply do not work for many types of work in the modern economy. In fact, the carrot or stick approach can actually diminish workers' performance over time. (The notable exception is that these approaches can be effective for workers who do routine, repetitive tasks, that require little creativity or individual initiative.) Pink shows that for many types of work, money is not the most powerful incentive. He shows that paying expected bonuses can actually diminish productivity, creativity, and performance over time.    Drive's main point is that the most effective way to motivate people is to pay them fairly and create a work environment that fosters autonomy, mastery, and a sense of purpose. The book cites several interesting examples of organizations that have created new and highly successful models for motivating their workforces.     Drive is an important book. Plus it's a quick and entertaining read. I highly recommend that any manager or employer who wants to get the very best from his/her employees at all levels ought to study Drive, as well as First Break All the Rules by Marcus Buckingham.

0783225857|5.0|Talk about the legacy of acting legend Gregory Peck.  This compelling actor played two of the most iconic characters in all of cinematic lore--[[ASIN:B00005AUKA Captain Ahab]] and Atticus Finch.  (And Peck played both roles in his own unique, creative style.)  With respect to Atticus Finch, Peck merely enhances an extraordinarily good film, TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD, based on Harper Lee's phenomenal and timeless [[ASIN:0061120081 novel]].  I've read the book and seen the movie, many times; experiencing both are extremely rewarding.  In particular, the film works marvelously, for several reasons.<br /><br />For openers, Horton Foote penned a riveting screenplay, while director Robert Mulligan brings Lee's novel to vivid life.  The film is blessed with very believable child actors in Mary Badham (Scout) and Phillip Alford (Jem), who both made their silver screen debuts.  The supporting cast is spectacular, including a grisly, disheveled James Anderson playing villain Bob Ewell and a very young Robert Duvall playing reclusive Boo Radley.  Add to that Peck's commanding performance as a widowed lawyer and father of two children in the Jim Crow South during the Great Depression, and TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD is a movie for the ages. 0385341008|4.0|It's amazing how a book solely composed of letters could get so deeply into characterization and plot.  There is a great story within the pages of The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society.  The authors did a tremendous job putting you in the hearts and minds of these ever so amusing characters.  For the most part the story here is light-hearted and full of hope and happiness, but that is not to say that there is no sadness, tragedy, and physical and emotional pain mixed in.  The beauty and happiness of the people living on Guernsey Island is borne through brutal hardships brought upon by the Germans during the WWII occupation.<br /><br />The book's flaw:  It took about a hundred pages before I started to enjoy the story.  The first ninety or so pages took me a while to get through, partly because I was getting used to the epistolary writing method and partly because it took some time to even care what the characters were writing about.  By the halfway point (book two) I was fully engrossed and although the ending was predictable, it was satisfying and appropriate. 0316044938|4.0|The Lovely Bones is written from the most interesting point of view I have seen in a book. This story is written from the point of view of Suzie Salmon, a young girl who was raped and murdered by a man in her own neighborhood. She then continues to tell the story from her position in her heaven. While intriguing and well developed, this is not a story that I would recommend to just any reader.     The Lovely Bones is a story of murder, rape, adultery and a family falling apart after the loss of their oldest child. These moral issues make this a book for a mature audience that thinks carefully about what they want to expose themselves to before they pick up this book. The rape and murder scene alone is very explicit and enough to make any adult's blood run cold. In addition to this there are other moments that portray strong sexual ideas, often outside a marriage relationship.      From her heaven Suzie Salmon is able to watch what is going on in the world beneath her and can see her family's life continue after her death. She can see the way her dad obsesses over Mr. Harvey, the suspicious man down the street that killed her, but he can't prove it. She can see the way that Mr. Harvey finds joy in his crime and how he prizes the trinkets he has collected from each of his victims. She can see the way that her mother pulls away from the rest of the family and clings to simpler times. She can watch her little brother and sister grow up and be the kids in school that everyone looks at funny because they're the dead girl's siblings. As Suzie watches all of this she tries to communicate with someone still on earth to tell them that Mr. Harvey is her killer, or that they should move on with their lives. She finds a very unexpected ally in this but no one listens to the weird girl in school, giving Suzie no way to help her family.      This book is a wonderful read as long as the reader is prepared to deal with the moral and psychological issues addressed within its pages. The writing is outstanding and the story will keep you turning the pages all the way to the very end. It is only then that the characters and reader of this story find a sense of peace and are able to let Suzie Salmon enjoy her heaven while they enjoy their lives.

Paul and John were much too extreme in their respective charming showman and curmudgeonly angry-young-man cynic, but George had a nicely measured blend of both, and it is apparent in this album.      Since all albums typically open with a strong lead-in track, \\"I'll Have You Anytime\\" seems to be an odd choice on the surface, but its production stays with you and packs a punch.  It immediately sets the tone for the entire album, and the remastering brings out the underlying atmosphere of the recording that I knew was there before, but it's more apparent now.  It's one of the songs that bears repeated listening.  It really makes you want to reach out to people you love.  It's devastating.  \\"My Sweet Lord\\" and \\"Wah-Wah\\" are his versions of \\"Plastic Ono Band - Primal Album\\" material.  Reaching out to God for peace and lambasting his former bandmates for giving him headaches (to say the very least) are just as potent as Lennon's \\"Love\\" and \\"I Found Out\\" as well as, ironically enough, \\"God\\".  John and George are both basically saying they'd had enough of Paul Mc Cartney, that he was making them physically ill and that he made himself out to be much more than he actually was, thereby suffocating the two, and they have to break away from the Beatle thing or else they'll both go insane.      \\"Isn't It A Pity\\" packs a punch in so many ways.  It not only echoed Lennon's feelings about society in general, but it's also George's way of smirking in Paul's face as a parody of the structure of Paul's beloved \\"Hey Jude\\" with its simple acoustic guitar opening leading to the bombastic coda repeating \\"what a pity\\", not to mention the song's 7-plusminute length.  Thankfully, George was wise enough to not do any annoying scat singing at the end.      This album has so much bright about it that it bears a separate review for each side, so that's exactly what I'm doing here.  Individual reviews of sides 2, 3 and 4 will follow on their own, then I'll have as look at the bonus tracks.      It's getting a bit late, so I must be on my way to face another day.

Yorke sings atop this with his voice sounding like it's being forced through a metallic filter. 0307266303|5.0|I haven't read much Mark Twain, so that quote was new to me, buried deep in the pages of Born To Run. And boy did it strike a chord. For somebody who hasn't run a mile in about a decade (since I left the Army), this book has been a revelation that struck deep into my psyche. It rings a bell. Without researching for myself the scientists, the science, and the studies cited in this book, deep down inside me I know all of it to be true.    And this coming from an obese, couch-loving, potato chip-munching American. I don't hate running. I loathe it. I don't ever remember myself running for fun after the age of 10. I ran to get away from rabid dogs, I ran to get away from the imaginary monsters my friends and I created to spook each other in the dark. In middle school I ran because I joined a soccer team (and the only reason I joined the soccer team was because the alternative was to wear a silly Boy Scouts uniform.) I ran because the Jesuit school I went to used running as a form of punishment (talk back to a teacher, run 5 laps around the back field).     By the time I was 14, I stopped running. I rollerbladed, I skated, I hiked, but I stopped running. That, combined with my new-found love of cheeseburgers, video games, and books, skyrocketed my weight from a svelte 120bs to 185 by the time I turned 17, when I joined the US Army to be an Infantryman.    Running wasn't fun in the Army. I had difficulty meeting the run portion of the required Army Physical Fitness Test. I could do push-ups and sit-ups for days, but couldn't run to save my life. This was attributed to my overweight physique, but after losing 30lbs during Basic Training I still just barely managed to pass the run, squeaking in with 20 seconds to spare. I didn't know it at that time, but I have exercise-induced asthma, the faster I inhale air, the faster my airways shut down.    My career in the Army Infantry didn't last long. As good as I was with everything else about the job, I couldn't run. In the Infantry that was perceived as a weakness. Tired with all the political games I had to play to stay cozy with the tribe I opted to take an early out under honorable conditions. I vowed never to run again after that.     My weight soon ballooned from 180 (which was my maintenance weight in the Army) to 225 (in a span of 6 months). Alarmed, I joined Golds Gym, took to weighlifting with a passion, but kept my cardio to 30-minutes on the treadmill or eliptical for warm ups. I turned into the Neanderthal mentioned in this book, too much muscle, and I was ingesting everything short of steroids to keep/build my muscle mass.    Then my back, which was plaguing me in the Army, started giving me issues again. So I stopped working out altogether, leading a sedentary lifestyle. Office job, fast food, couches, books, and video games. Three years later, at age 24, I was being plagued by migraine headaches to the point of vomiting. I showed up at the doctor's office with a blood-pressure of 240/160. The medical personnel were astonished that I was even walking and talking. Turns out my kidneys were shutting down, cause: idiopathic (docspeak for \\"who the f knows\\"). After 9 months of dialysis I was granted a reprieve, a kidney transplant. That came with it's own set of issues, heavy doses of Prednisone for one. Again my weight shot up from 200 to 250 in about 6 months. 4 years later, I'm still fighting to maintain my weight at 230.    Which brings me to the present. Over 3 years ago, in an effort to combat the weight-gain effects of steroids, I turned to the Filipino Martial Art of Eskrima for some physical activity. Six months ago I read an article on the web about Vibram Five Fingers, interesting, maybe I can use those as lightweight footwear in Eskrima for added stability without exposing my feet to bacteria-laden gym mats (MRSA-anyone?). Then my back felt better. Cool, unexpected, but nice. Occasionally I'd read about the VFFs online (while spreading the message to friends) and I'd catch glimpses about the book Born To Run. I ignored it for months, until the other day I ended up with an hour to kill at the mall, then I remembered the book. Bought it from the bookstore.    Last night I read the book during commercials in between watching LOST. I kept reading until 3 in the morning. I giggled, I laughed, I shed a tear or two. I am an atheist, but what I experienced last night must be what some folks feel when they discover religion. Between these pages I believe I have found the answers as to why I'm sick. Why I don't expect to live past 40. With a kidney transplant under my belt, fending off heart disease and diabetes at 31 I really don't expect to live a long life.    Now, I don't know if there's a salvation to come with my revelation. I don't know if it's too late to try. I don't know if I can run around the block without passing out. I don't know if I can give up meats that I love so much.    But I damn sure aim to try... yo soy El Javali...

He states, that he is not certified in changing unconscious beliefs and refers for that matter to PSYCH-K.<br /><br />Personally, Bruce Liptons book - and the following I've read and studied - changed my life 180 degrees and has given me emotionally, physically, professionally and monetary a fulfillment which I would never have dreamed of before.<br /><br />But then again: These new discoveries are for those who are able, willing and open to understand them. And if you do: nothing can hold you back to realize yourself the way you want to!!<br /><br />[[ASIN:0743276965 The Intention Experiment: Using Your Thoughts to Change Your Life and the World]][[ASIN:006143518X The Field: The Quest for the Secret Force of the Universe]][[ASIN:0975935402 PSYCH-K...The Missing Peace In Your Life!]][[ASIN:1401925804 Spontaneous Evolution: Our Positive Future (and a Way to Get There from Here)]]
B0000WN0ZK|3.0|Michelangelo Antonioni has proved hit or miss with me.  I've seen a few of his films and have either openly LOVED them or, sadly, openly hated them (I know that hate is a strong word, so maybe I just didn't `get' them).  I am kind of somewhere in the middle when it comes to `Blow Up'.  It is a movie that is rich with meaning, but it has a hard time establishing that `meaning'.<br /><br />I feel that maybe the effort put in was stronger than the result.<br /><br />The film centers around a vain fashion photographer who, while searching to find more meaning in his work, attempts to take some candid photos for a magazine.  The photos are of a couple frolicking in an open field.  When he actually gets the chance to develop the film though, he finds that there is more to these pictures than the sweet innocence of love he initially thought he was capturing.  Instead, he slowly (and methodically) uncovers a gun and what appears to be a corpse.<br /><br />There are moments within `Blow Up' that seem to speak so loudly about the directors point of view and the emotional response we are supposed to carry from this film, but sometimes those moments can find themselves lost in the structure of the film.  For me, the vapid existence of the protagonist, Thomas, is the point of the whole film.  While the poignant scenes such as the zombie-like rock concert, the strangely aggressive three-way or the ambiguous `high' party are all key elements to the films unraveling, they can feel almost too abrasive and too `present'.  There are no subtleties in this film and so it comes across almost a little too blunt, to the point where it's hard to take seriously.<br /><br />I wouldn't be quick to say `style over substance' because there is a lot of substance here, I just feel like the style is so thick it outweighs the substance.<br /><br />Another little quibble I have with this film is that it feels very, very dated.  There are films that, while reflecting an era, are able to transcend all time and feel fresh and poignant even today.  For me, `Blow Up' is so much a 60's film that it lacks any feeling of relevance today.  That isn't to say that it isn't relevant (the overall message presented within Thomas's take on the murder in general is very relevant) but it is presented in a way that feels too `past' to make a real impact today.  I don't know how to really explain what I mean, and I hope that isn't coming across as self indulgent, but it was a real feeling I had while watching the film.  It just feels far too `60's'.<br /><br />This is coming from a guy who considers the 60's to be THE best decade for cinema.<br /><br />As far as performances are concerned, the only real standout is Vanessa Redgrave, who proves to be just as captivating in her early years as she is now.  She's a marvelous actress, and her ambiguous approach to her character's panic stricken conscience is rather refreshing and completely engaging.<br /><br />I wish she had more screen time.<br /><br />In the end I have to say that I appreciate the film, I just don't think it's all there.  I was expecting something totally different, something that really struck me on all levels; but it failed to do so.  I can understand the attraction, for Antonioni is a very visual director (this film is littered with marvelous screenshots) and his contrast between the glossed over fake `real world' and the gritty and almost haunting world presented in the photographs is a stellar and meaningful observation (and, in my humble opinion, that closing `mime' scene was pure genius), but if I'm being honest with myself then I must acknowledge the fact that, while it is all here, it isn't presented in the best way.  It loses a lot of its impact because Antonioni didn't feel the need to pull back the `style' so as to expose the `substance'.today.  For me, `Blow Up' is so much a 60's film that it lacks any feeling of relevance today.  That isn't to say that it isn't relevant (the overall message presented within Thomas's take on the murder in general is very relevant) but it is presented in a way that feels too `past' to make a real impact today.  I don't know how to really explain what I mean, and I hope that isn't coming across as self indulgent, but it was a real feeling I had while watching the film.  It just feels far too `60's'.    This is coming from a guy who considers the 60's to be THE best decade for cinema.    As far as performances are concerned, the only real standout is Vanessa Redgrave, who proves to be just as captivating in her early years as she is now.  She's a marvelous actress, and her ambiguous approach to her character's panic stricken conscience is rather refreshing and completely engaging.    I wish she had more screen time.    In the end I have to say that I appreciate the film, I just don't think it's all there.  I was expecting something totally different, something that really struck me on all levels; but it failed to do so.  I can understand the attraction, for Antonioni is a very visual director (this film is littered with marvelous screenshots) and his contrast between the glossed over fake `real world' and the gritty and almost haunting world presented in the photographs is a stellar and meaningful observation (and, in my humble opinion, that closing `mime' scene was pure genius), but if I'm being honest with myself then I must acknowledge the fact that, while it is all here, it isn't presented in the best way.  It loses a lot of its impact because Antonioni didn't feel the need to pull back the `style' so as to expose the `substance'.
1572705175|5.0|I have tried a number of times to get into this author's work because my friends have recommended his work for years. Wit, hilarity, irony are frequent words tossed about in reference to his work. On every prior effort I've failed to \\"get it\\". I finally got it in two formats to break this impasse, if indeed it was breakable. First, I got the audio version of JEEVES & WOOSTER, narrated by Martin Jarvis. Then I watched the Video version with Hugh Laurie and Stephen Fry. I am happy to report that I finally \\"get\\" the humor and fun which readers of Wodehouse have long enjoyed. If you too have had trouble getting into the wit behind the work, I suggest you do the same.<br /><br />The stories revolve around a well connected English gentleman, Bertie Wooster, who is as idle as can be. There are lords and ladies in his family. He did go to Eton and Oxford and now belongs to all the right clubs. However, the way he behaves, is the way most men of his class behaved in England back in his day, when automobiles were first coming out. You do see Bertie tooling about in his roadster.  Bertie is funny but you are most definitely laughing at Bertie, not with him. He is likable but does not have much but air between his ears.<br /><br />Jeeves is as opposite from Bertie as can be. Jeeves is of the working class, Bertie's valet. He is suave, intelligent, well read, shrewd and manipulative. Also, he is always calm and collected, never losing his cool.  In each and every story, it is Jeeves who rescues Bertie, his friends or his family members after they have gotten themselves (always) into some ferocious mess of their own making. Just with picking out potential marital partners, they are all utter disasters.<br /><br />A big part of my problem with Wodehouse and J&W was simply being American. In this same era in America, a well born, well educated man like Bertie would be considered a sluggard for accomplishing nothing. That he could go to (by comparison) Andover and Yale, after being born into a prominent American family, yet be such an idiot that his valet had to do his thinking for him, would not be the making of an American satire! That Bertie and all his friends regard any form of work as beyond the pale is also about as un American a concept as there could be. This classic of wit and satire could only come from England since it revolves around the concept and conceit of the idle English gentleman in that era.<br /><br />Jarvis is absolutely splendid in all roles.  I like Wodehouse much better on audio than on the printed page.<br /><br />Visit my blog with link given on my profile page here or use this phonetically given URL (livingasseniors dot blogspot dot com). 0061703257|5.0|Paranoia is typically considered a bad thing.  It is, of course, a mental illness.  However, we are all prone to it.  This book, set in 1954, couldn't take place during a more paranoid time in America.  There are frequent references to HUAC, freeing of concentration camps from the Nazis, and other references from the start of the Cold War. The actual action takes place at the perfect place for paranoia though, at a mental hospital for the criminally insane on an island off the coast of Massachusetts. Teddy, a federal marshall, is on this island to ostensibly solve the case of a woman who has disappeared from the island, a dangerous criminal since she killed her three children.  Teddy becomes immediately enmeshed by the extreme paranoia which grips everyone on the island.  It seems as if everyone and everything could be part of a conspiracy.  Everyone is paranoid and Teddy trusts no one.  During the course of his trying to solve his case though, he will deal with a basic truth about paranoia: it displaces those realities which people cannot live inside because they are too painful. The novel is receiving increased notice now because of the release of Martin Scorsese's movie of the same starring Leonardo DiCaprio. The film follows to the letter the course of the novel and even manages to enhance it to Hitchcockian levels.  Both are splendid works and you can't go wrong with either. Lehane's novels seem to make excellent movies as there at least three that I can count originating with him: this one, Mystic River made by Clint Eastwood and Gone, Baby Gone made by Ben Affleck.  All of them involve great tragedies but not the tragedies one is necessarily expecting.<br /><br />Visit my blog with link given on my profile page here or use this phonetically given URL (livingasseniors dot blogspot dot com). B001FB55H6|4.0|Who watches the Watchmen?  I did, and you should too.    Leading up to the seeing the film, I watched the motion comic, which is a word-for-word animation of the graphic novel minus some interstitial material.  It had been many years since I read the comic and I really didn't remember anything.  Wow, the story is so great.  It puts most every other comic I've ever read to shame.  I love Watchmen.    The movie is very close to the comic.  Many scenes of the movie are also word-for-word with the graphic novel.  There are a couple of relatively minor changes and one major change in the ending that, as you will see if you visit such forums, is hotly debated.  A lot of fans of the comic hate the change that was made but I don't think it's that big a deal.  The spirit of the ending remains the same - the change is in some ways more of a mechanical one, and in other ways I even think it works better than the way it was in the comic.  You'll have to decide that for yourself if you are a big fan of the comic.    The movie itself is very well done.  The directing is great, as are the special effects.  Most of the actors are good.  The guy who plays Rorschach is particularly excellent in his role and really brought the character to life.  There is one particular detractor here - Malin Akerman plays Silk Spectre II and her acting is rather uneven.  By uneven I mean that she's great when she is quiet and I'm looking at her, and even better when she is naked.  When she starts talking, that's when we run into problems.  Big parts of the plot revolve around her character and she's just not good enough to pull off the emotional scenes required.  She is the sole reason for a 4 star rating instead of 5.    My recommendation is definitely to see Watchmen.
B0025KVLTC|5.0|Was there any other band in the history of rock and roll that evolved as fast as The Beatles?  Within a few short years, the Liverpool lads would go from making simple pop music (VERY good pop music, mind you) to creating the most influential music in history.  Revolver is an important step in that process and contains some of my favorite Beatles' songs, including \\"She Said She Said\\", \\"Eleanor Rigby\\", \\"Taxman\\", and \\"Got To Get You Into My Life\\".  Not only was the music amazing, but Revolver was a technical masterpiece as well, employing the latest recording techniques of the day.<br /><br />Revolver was the first of the 2009 Beatles' remasters I purchased, replacing my original CD version.  In my opinion, the remaster is far superior to the original CD release.  There's more separation between the instruments, each now having a distinct voice.  It's almost like being in the room with the band while they're playing.  The recordings just feel a little more alive to me now, with subtle details I hadn't noticed on the original CD.  My one complaint with the reissue packaging would be the lack of a plastic tray to insert the CD into.  Sliding the discs in and out of the cardboard sleeve will eventually lead to scratching, so I've taken to storing the discs themselves separate from the artwork to better preserve them.  The album booklets are printed on thick glossy paper for a nice effect, but I don't think the packaging would have been spoiled by the addition of that plastic tray.  I've seen plenty of other albums that are a combination of cardboard and plastic that look just fine.<br /><br />The album is amazing and sounds better on CD than it ever has before.  Highly recommended.

0061922315|5.0|Asha is born to a couple in India, Kavita and Jasu. They want a family, but in poverty stricken India, baby girls are not welcome. Kavita's first born was a girl and was killed because of her gender. Kavita does not want the same fate for her second child, and takes Asha to an orphanage. Somer and Krishnan are American doctors and are unable to have children. Krishnan, who is of Indian heritage, convinces his wife to adopt a child from India. It is baby Asha that they choose.<br /><br />This book is so well-written. The words and the paragraphs are like poetry and I found myself sucked in by it. The characters are fascinating. The three women tell the story from their perspectives over a span of 25 years. From their tales, the reader understands the difficulties of having a family in India versus in America. The challenges of poverty are so different from those of a family of doctors in San Francisco, but both couples have troubles nonetheless. Kavita longs to know what became of her daughter. Somer worries that Asha will be out of reach due to her Indian heritage and her bond with her adoptive father. Asha wants to know why she was given up and learn about her birth country. All three women learn about mothers, families, and India as they search to fill their individual voids and find happiness and peace of mind.<br /><br />Secret Daughter is an engaging page-turner. I thoroughly enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone with a love of reading.

I would give six if I could.

0805091742|2.0|Essentially, the book is a collection of anecdotes with distressful outcomes; each alluding to a human error. For each story, the author argues that if a checklist is prepared and that checklist addressed the specific human error, the world would be a better place. Perfunctorily, this appeals to us, maybe because we enjoy dwelling on \\"what-if\\" scenarios: \\"only if the surgeon had ..., a life would have been save\\". The fallacy is that the checklist would be humongous because it will have to address many other potential human errors, and that would take an inordinately long time to go through, for example, by a surgeon before an operation.    In the introduction, a person nearly dies because the anesthesiologist administered a dose of potassium a hundred times higher than intended. This caused asystole. What kind of a simple checklist could have averted this situation? Would it be worth for everyone in the operating room to spend time on this checklist before each operation? There are likely to be hundreds of mistakes an anesthesiologist can make, and there are likely to be hundreds of reasons for asystole.     Simple checklists are used more often than the author surmises, though they are not named as such. For example, in my work, software, our project management timelines are essentially checklists. When I go hiking, the leader provides a list of dos and don'ts, and a list of safety items to bring. These are checklists. When assigned a new project, I note down important steps. If I had to do a similar project again, I use this bullet list so I do not repeat mistakes and perform tasks faster.    update (March 6 2010): The book does not give a single illustrative example of a checklist, although there are lots of anecdotes mentioning that checklists dramatically improved outcomes, or tantalizingly suggesting checklist use. The author could have shown prototype checklists, at least for the stories where checklists have purportedly benefited.    Also, a chunk of the book is about inter-personal communications; that renders the title misleading.

B0030BYWKU|3.0|Jason Der&uuml;lo's self-titled debut is one that is full of promise, though comes over at times as bit predictable.  'Predictable' describes a great bit of today's pop music, though every now and then, some left-field smash, much like \\"Um Whatcha Say\\" comes around and breaks the mold.  [[ASIN:B0030BYWKU Jason Derulo]] isn't a bad album, in fact there are enough promising moments to make this 32 minute affair more than enjoyable, however, you'd be hard pressed to find anything that topples \\"Um Whatcha Say\\".  Sure, tracks like \\"In My Head\\" and the range-showing \\"The Sky's The Limit\\" standout, but haven't we already heard tracks like this from Usher and Chris Brown in the past?  That's my main complaint with this debut.  Der&uuml;lo has a great voice (not necessarily more distinctive than anybody else), but solid.<br /><br />\\"Um Whatcha Say\\" is the shining moment, as expected by anyone who purchased this effort.  The production is perfect and it is something different in a saturated urban market.  Not surprising the Imogen Heap sampling track shot to #1.  What more is there to say, it's a rare 5-star track.  \\"Ridin' Solo\\" is certainly catchy, cool urban-pop at its best, but it brings nothing new to the table overall.  Like Jay Sean's good, but \\"tried and true\\" [[ASIN:B002SEW5Y0 All or Nothing]], the track and the album itself feel more like we're retreading already treaded turf.  With that said, \\"Ridin' Solo\\", again, is pretty addictive.<br /><br />Second single \\"In My Head\\" is good, though it suffers the \\"sophomore effect\\" in comparison to monster hit \\"Um Whatcha Say\\".  Despite this, the track has become a top ten staple on the pop charts, which is good for Der&uuml;lo.  Sure, I prefer \\"Um Whatcha Say\\", but \\"In My Head\\" smartly opts for hard drums and catchy songwriting.  Vocally, Der&uuml;lo sounds great.  As far as showing off prodigious vocal range and solid vocal performance, \\"The Sky's The Limit\\" shows one of Der&uuml;lo's best vocal moments of the entire album.  The electronic production recalls Chris Brown's \\"Forever\\" (a song I was never crazy about), but for this track, it works.  \\"What If\\" finally slows things down in an album that seems like an adrenaline rush, showing the softer side of Der&uuml;lo.  It stands out - in the scope of this album at least.  \\"Love Hangover\\" is solid, though nothing revolutionary, again a problem with this album in my mind.  \\"Encore\\" revives a bit of momentum, reminding the urban listener of Usher.  Again, the producers opt for more electronic helmed production, and it grows a bit weary on the listener, particularly on an R&B album.  While the problem of overwrought keyboards and synths isn't a problem on this album as it is on say Ke$ha's [[ASIN:B002XNEII2 Animal]], it still grates on one's nerves slightly. \\"Encore\\" is solid, despite my minor quibbles.<br /><br />\\"Fallen\\" reminds one of a Ne-Yo track, despite not being penned by the R&B singer-songwriter or the Stargate production team.  Not bad, it also isn't truly exceptional - middle of the road.  Closing track \\"Blind\\" ends the brief affair on a solid note, even if it never quite reaches the \\"epicness\\" of say \\"The Sky's The Limit\\" or mega slow jam \\"What If\\".  Good closing track, nonetheless.<br /><br />Essentially,  'Jason Der&uuml;lo' is a solid affair, but ultimately aside from mega hit \\"Um Whatcha Say\\", it doesn't necessarily bring anything new to the table.  Sure the production is crisp (sometimes to electronically derived) and of course Der&uuml;lo can sing, but I think that his self-titled debut shows more potential and promise than a truly cohesive set of R&B/pop gems.  3 - 3 1/2 stars in my eyes.ls Chris Brown's \\"Forever\\" (a song I was never crazy about), but for this track, it works.  \\"What If\\" finally slows things down in an album that seems like an adrenaline rush, showing the softer side of Derlo. Not bad, it also isn't truly exceptional - middle of the road.  Closing track \\"Blind\\" ends the brief affair on a solid note, even if it never quite reaches the \\"epicness\\" of say \\"The Sky's The Limit\\" or mega slow jam \\"What If\\". All in all a solid release... easily their best to date.

B00008A7QK|4.0|Electric Warrior does not quite reach the heights Marc Bolland and T-Rex soon would on [[ASIN:B000FVGN00 The Slider]]- a lusher and more quirky album. But being one foot from the top of Everest is quite a nice position.<br /><br />Electric Warrior may be one of the great cases for rock and roll. Back in 1971, when progressive heavy was wrapping its roots around the bedrock, T-Rex proved that you could take almost 1950s style, and make it sound modern and yes, progressive.<br /><br />Hear \\"Mambo Sun,\\" \\"Jeepster,\\" any track you happen to random on the CD player is self contained and basic rock.<br /><br />Sort of: and that \\"sort of's name in Tony Visconti.<br /><br />Visconti was working with Bowie, and perhaps more relevant here, Gentle Giant--one of the most complex of the Vertigo or any label's progressive bands.<br /><br />But Visconti also gave equally loving care to straight rock and roll, which he was as emotionally invested in as prog. The strings and thick layers on all these tracks make them as juicy and delicious as anything on Vertigo or any art rock.<br /><br />This is a rock and roll album, and thanks to Bolland as well as producer Visconti, an extremely smart one. Basic rock became glam and grand, and as musical and delectable with 1970s production as opposed to that of the 1950s.<br /><br />When you had to be fantastic in the 1970s  just to be thought of as good among rocks most diverse and extensive population, ever, T-Rex and Electric Warrior stuck out like a healthy thumb for kids who wanted to put down the Hammond B-3s, put on that diamond star face paint, and simply rock
B002SJIO5E|4.0|Making some interesting points about how people often interact with minority groups, \\"District 9\\" is more than your standard story about aliens. An alien ship has come to Earth and the aliens have been forced to live in a shantytown in South Africa for 20 years. The movie focuses on how people treat these new neighbors. There are graphic scenes with dead and mutilated bodies (mostly alien) plus weapons which tear people apart, so it isn't for the squeamish. Personally, I cringed a bit at the start but got used to the nauseating parts about halfway through the movie. The story is rather interesting, the acting is decent, and the directing is well done, so it was worth it. The aliens done by Weta, the same company behind \\"Lord of the Rings\\" and \\"Avatar\\", are very different and yet realistic.    There are basically two parts to this movie - the documentary-style build-up showing the conditions the aliens are forced to live in, and the pursuit after one of the humans starts to cooperate with the aliens. The human in question, Wikus, is in charge of a team from MNU, a weapons corporation designated to evict the aliens from their shanties so they can be moved to even smaller concentration camp style quarters. At the start Wikus dislikes the prawns (a derogatory term for the aliens) as much as anyone. During the eviction operation, Wikus accidentally gets exposed to a substance which starts to transform him slowly into an alien. Since the alien weaponry can only be unlocked by their DNA, Wikus becomes the one man who can fire them. Headed by his father-in-law, MNU wants the ability to utilize the weaponry at all costs, including Wikus' death.    Wikus manages to escape capture and is aided by one of the aliens and the alien's son. The alien is trying to travel home and the two form a cautious alliance. To accomplish their goals, they are up against the corporation as well as Nigerian gangs who have similar designs on using the alien weaponry. Being in close contact with the alien, Wikus learns more about them and gains a better appreciation for their situation.    One can easily draw parallels between how the humans in the movie treat the aliens and how various minority groups have been treated over time. The humans don't actively try to learn anything about the aliens; therefore, as an unknown, the aliens become something to fear and battle against. They get pushed aside and scorned. When it comes down to it though, the aliens are very much like the humans. They have similar emotions, children whom they care for, and just want to go home.
B00000342V|5.0|There are times as an avid listener of massive amounts of music when we, without being aware we are, dismiss what is well known. We have had Sgt. Pepper or the White Album or another universally known record that we have listened to almost since infancy. We either forget it in our quest for learning the unknown--or, we throw it on as background when we are at a loss of what we thirst for.<br /><br />It is not that we ever stop loving this music. But like an old lover, we forget why we love in the first place.<br /><br />Then one day, we step back from the flame, and.........WOW! That tingle through the bones we forgot is back. We are older, more tired, but that moment comes, as do tears to the eyes.<br /><br />Today, I took that unwitting step with an old valentine, Curtis Mayfield's Superfly. Yep: the wonderful tears and the wonderful tingle came. If you are reading,  no explanation is needed. But then I remembered why Superfly, and Curtis, occupy that top top top top level where the air is different and the music is the most important music. Viscerally and intellectually, we remember.<br /><br />Superfly of course works on both levels: back in the early 1970s when funk and sweet soul were two very different mediums, Curtis Mayfield did not combine but made synergy. Listen to \\"Freddie's Dead\\" or \\"Pusherman\\" and hear how Master Mayfield mixes the toughest beats with the softest strings--how the music both soothes and attacks. DJ's now don't sample sweet soul for beats, but \\"Freddie's Dead\\" being one of the world's best orchestrated AND most sampled songs is no mistake.<br /><br />Only Curtis could do this, and if the music didn't bring the tears and tingles and dances the musical constructions would not much. But the emotions come and the music means everything.<br /><br />And it means everything because Mayfield made it so how Mayfield exclusively could. Superfly came in 1972: about when the Civil Rights movement was ending and the African American Community, in some parts, started turning against itself. With drugs and crime and helped by white apathy.<br /><br />Mayfield had his finger not on the pulse but the vain of the black struggle back with the Impressions in the early 60s, before he could even write about it. Finally he was able.<br /><br />Mayfield must have felt the shift from the 1960s to the 1970s. On Superfly. In 1969 it was about a \\"Choice Of Colors.\\" In 1972, it was the \\"Pusherman.\\" Mayfield of course, outlines in literate detail. \\"We can deal with rockets and dreams,\\" he sings on \\"Freddie's Dead.\\" \\"But reality, what does it mean?\\" Mayfield is both abstract and concrete at the same time.<br /><br />Essential for understanding black music, rock music, funk music, soul music. All music/<br /><br />That is Curtis Mayfield.h drugs and crime and helped by white apathy.     Mayfield had his finger not on the pulse but the vain of the black struggle back with the Impressions in the early 60s, before he could even write about it. Finally he was able.    Mayfield must have felt the shift from the 1960s to the 1970s. On Superfly. In 1969 it was about a \\"Choice Of Colors.\\" In 1972, it was the \\"Pusherman.\\" Mayfield of course, outlines in literate detail. \\"We can deal with rockets and dreams,\\" he sings on \\"Freddie's Dead.\\" \\"But reality, what does it mean?\\" Mayfield is both abstract and concrete at the same time.    Essential for understanding black music, rock music, funk music, soul music. All music/    That is Curtis Mayfield.
0380725398|4.0|Having fallen in love with Rebecca by Daphne DuMaurier, I was anxious to read something else by her.  I was not disappointed with Jamaica Inn.<br /><br />It's the 1800's and Mary Yellan is a twenty three year old woman who has lived her life on a farm in Helston. She helped her mother with the family farm after her father passed away. When her mother loses her will to live, she shares with Mary her final wish. She says that Mary is to go to live with her Aunt Patience in Bodmin after she dies. Patience' husband Joss Merlyn is the Innkeeper of Jamaica Inn.<br /><br />Mary arrives at the gloomy inn, and is shocked by the woman her Aunt Patience has become. Formerly outgoing and cheerful,  now she is nervous, quiet, aloof and frightened. Her husband, Joss is creepy, mean and secretive, and Mary realizes early on that this is not a place for her or her aunt, as danger lurks within the crumbling inn.<br /><br />(p. 159....\\"She thought of Aunt Patience, trailing like a ghost in the shadow of her master, and she shuddered. That would be Mary Yellen too, but for the Grace of God and her own strength and will.\\"<br /><br />Mary wants to escape but she is torn because of the promise she made to her mother. She feels her aunt is not safe with Joss, an alcoholic, and she wants Aunt Patience to escape as well. Strange things are going on at the inn on the Cornish coast.  I don't want to give spoilers, but there are never any guests and is not even open to the public, and secretive things happen late at night at Jamaica Inn.<br /><br />MY THOUGHTS  - If you like Gothic novels, and stories that evoke the atmosphere of horror and dread, then this novel should be perfect for you.<br /><br />RECOMMENDED - 4.5/5 stars

1605092762|5.0|The most encouraging read on community development/poverty reduction in years.<br />Refreshing is not often a word I use for such books. We discovered drip irrigation three years ago and have set up test sites in three West African countries. I almost cried when I stumbled on the concept, it was so simple, economical; the best way to help poor people period. We felt alone in drip project, as very few heard of small drip irrigation, and even less seemed interested. Now that we discovered Paul's book, we don't feel so alone, and have been encouraged.<br />We need Local suppliers in every country of West Africa willing to market, as Polak writes, to the $1 a day or less, realizing volume sales will come quickly. We cannot continue to order and ship supplies as individual NGO's or organizations, for our own purposes. It's wasting time, money, and resources.<br /><br />Every backpacker, tourist and visitor to Africa & Asia should have a small drip irrigation kit in their backpack, to install for a local families they know. 0307454541|3.0|As the start of a \\"thriller trilogy,\\" The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo does an excellent job of introducing and developing characters, telling one rather interesting tale of a twisted, dysfunctional family with a host of dirty secrets, and lassoing readers into the world of Swedish intrigue. Before I read this novel (which, in the original Swedish, is actually entitled Men Who Hate Women--a much more accurate title), I knew the basic elements of the main story, and Larsson does a great job of building suspense as he tells the story of the Vanger family and its dark history. The resolution of that story is something of a disappointment--it's plausible and well-plotted, but in terms of dramatic payoff, it's decidedly anticlimactic. The weakest part of the novel, however, is the framed story that's wrapped around the Gothic tale of the Vangers--Larsson's inner story competes with his framing story of journalistic integrity and corruption in the world of international finance. BIG YAWN. The two stories are connected tangentially, but the framed structure of the novel saps almost all of the inner story's intensity, and the book ends on a rather flat note. I am, however, eager to read the sequel, as well as the third book in the trilogy.
B002HREKCI|4.0|Thirteen Reasons is the story of Hannah Baker and as the book title suggests, 13 reasons why she died. All these reasons are in fact related to 13 people who helped her reach the state she did-the state where she felt like she had no other choice but to take her own life. Before she commits suicide, all the people who were somehow responsible for it were sent a set of tapes so that the person knows how much his/ her actions affected Hannah.<br /><br />Whenever I hear somebody committed suicide, my first thought is obviously \\"Why?\\", followed by thoughts like how can something this trivial force someone to take his/ her own life and leave so many unanswered questions and blame games behind. But it's almost never one thing; it's never \\"just\\" or \\"trivial\\". It's a culmination of many incidents and as Hannah says \\"A snowball effect\\". Thirteen Reasons Why shows exactly that, the other side of suicide, something which we would probably never get to see or should see.<br /><br />Hannah Baker is the new girl in town and like everyone else she finds it difficult to fit in. Hannah has left her own town and with that her old life which was filled with rumors and she hopes to start with a fresh slate. But things don't turn out how she wants them to. Rumors follow her in the new town as well, trusts are broken, games are played and at one point Hannah doesn't feel safe anymore, neither in her school nor at home.<br /><br />Clay Jensen is one of the guys who gets the set of tapes. The book is an intermingled narrative between Hannah's voice in the tape and Clay's thought process or rather his reactions to it. It helps the reader get a different perspective on Hannah's story. It also made it difficult for me to get into the story. The moment I felt I was getting involved in what Hannah was saying Clay would come up with totally unrelated things to say, not always unrelated, but many times. I know Clay's perspective was important too, but it wasn't done as well as it could have.<br /><br />The writing was okay. In fact I really didn't think I was going to like this book at all. Some where after the first 100 pages, the book really picks up pace. But I feel the power of the book lies in the story, in the message. To some people it will help realize how even their smallest of actions could affect someone's psyche if it was fragile enough. Teenagers usually tend to be insensitive and wrapped up in their own world, it would hopefully make them realize that everyone's worlds are overlapped and some things could have greater consequences than they realized. But on the other hand, it does not provide any hope to people who are probably thinking of giving up on the world like Hannah.<br /><br />I would say it's a good book which would probably be great for teenagers and adults as well.fact I really didn't think I was going to like this book at all. Some where after the first 100 pages, the book really picks up pace. But I feel the power of the book lies in the story, in the message. To some people it will help realize how even their smallest of actions could affect someone's psyche if it was fragile enough. Teenagers usually tend to be insensitive and wrapped up in their own world, it would hopefully make them realize that everyone's worlds are overlapped and some things could have greater consequences than they realized. But on the other hand, it does not provide any hope to people who are probably thinking of giving up on the world like Hannah.    I would say it's a good book which would probably be great for teenagers and adults as well.
